title: Markets to Focus on Fed's Inflation View Today; Some of Europe's Negative Bond Yields Turn Positive
text:
Top News

Fed Prepares to Taper, but Markets Crave More Insight on Rate Rises

The Federal Reserve is likely to announce Wednesday that it will begin steadily reducing its bond-buying program, the biggest step the central bank has taken toward reversing its pandemic-era stimulus.

The decision to wind down, or taper, those purchases this month has been so heavily telegraphed by Fed officials that the focus of the two-day meeting that ends Wednesday has shifted toward how they will characterize inflation risks—which carries important implications for how soon they might raise interest rates.

The Fed will release its postmeeting policy statement at 2 p.m. Eastern time. Fed Chairman Jerome Powell will follow with a press conference at 2:30 p.m. Here's what to watch.

Negative Bond Yields Recede in Europe

Negative bond yields are getting harder to find in Europe, shrinking the pool of debt that pays back less to investors than they put in. Behind the rise in yields is a bet that the European Central Bank will have to raise interest rates sooner than it wants, as inflation across Europe has hit multiyear highs.

Key Developments Around the World

Financial System Makes Big Promises on Climate Change at COP26

Most of the world's big banks, its major investors and insurers, and its financial regulators have for the first time signed up to a coordinated pledge that will incorporate carbon emissions into their most fundamental decisions.

World Leaders Vow to Cut Methane Emissions

Tariffs to Tackle Climate Change Gain Momentum

Malaysia's Central Bank Keeps Benchmark Rate at Record Low

Malaysia's central bank kept its benchmark interest rate at a historical low as economic growth risks remain tilted to the downside, though there have been some signs of recovery.

China Binges on U.S. Gas for Energy Shortage, Carbon Footprint

In 2019, China all but cut off imports of U.S. liquefied natural gas. Today, China is buying more gas from the U.S. than ever, a consequence of the global energy shortage and China's effort to reduce how much coal it burns.

Visa Restrictions Endanger U.S. Innovation Edge, Universities Say

American universities and research institutes say the U.S.'s dominance in science and technology could be undermined by toughened U.S. visa requirements that are squeezing the flow of talent from China.

Financial Regulation Roundup

Biden Picks Wall Street Critic to Oversee Large Banks

The Biden administration formally nominated Saule Omarova, a law professor and critic of big banks, to serve as a top banking regulator, a setback for Wall Street and other firms that had pushed to scuttle her nomination.

SEC Chairman Says Crypto Market Won't Mature Without Oversight

Securities and Exchange Commission Chairman Gary Gensler said the regulator will be "very active" in bringing the digital currency market under its investor protection framework, as the Biden administration increases scrutiny of cryptocurrencies.

Bond Investors Challenge Wall Street Greenwashing

As financial regulators in the U.S. and Europe scrutinize the investment industry for signs of misleading claims, or "greenwashing," some money managers are blackballing green bonds they say have loopholes for borrowers.

Barclays Sheds Jeffrey Epstein Ties, Keeps Wall Street Strategy

Jes Staley may be gone from Barclays, but C.S. Venkatakrishnan, appointed chief executive on Monday, will carry on his signature strategy of betting big on the U.K.'s last major presence on Wall Street.

FTC's Effort to Strengthen Online Privacy Protections Faces Hurdles

The Federal Trade Commission has outlined a far-reaching vision for protecting consumers' privacy online, but the plan faces challenges including budget constraints, personnel changes and potential legal pushback.

Hospitals Face Steeper Fines for Shunning Price-Disclosure Rules

The Biden administration finalized a regulation that will sharply increase the financial penalties for larger hospitals that don't make their prices public. The new rule, which will take effect at the start of 2022, will also crack down on practices that made hospitals' prices hard to find and access, including the use of special coding embedded in hospital webpages that prevents Google and other search engines from displaying price pages in search results.

Forward Guidance

Wednesday (all times ET)

8:30 a.m.: U.S. Commerce Department releases September international trade data

9 a.m.: Bank of Canada's Gravelle speaks on panel on climate risk management via videoconference

2 p.m.: U.S. Federal Reserve releases policy statement

2:30 p.m.: Fed's Powell holds press conference

Thursday

5 a.m.: Norges Bank releases interest-rate decision

8 a.m.: Bank of England releases monetary policy report, summary and minutes; European Central Bank's Lagarde gives speech at ECB-Center for Economic and Policy Research Women in Economics Conference

9:30 a.m.: Czech National Bank releases monetary policy decision

1:50 p.m.: Fed's Quarles speaks on panel on financial stability at Portuguese Securities Market Commission conference

2:50 p.m.: European Central Bank's Schnabel speaks on panel at ECB-Center for Economic and Policy Research Women in Economics Conference

Research

Climate Risk Disclosure by Large Banks Still Weak

Although some improvement has been seen over the past 18 months, climate risk disclosure by large banks of how climate change might affect their financial performance "remains weak," Moody's Investors Service says. A review of 28 U.S., European and Asian lenders with combined assets of $56 trillion showed "most banks focus on disclosing governance structures, policies, and processes to manage environmental risk rather than providing a clear assessment of how climate change might affect their lending and investment portfolios," Moody's adds. It also says that banks "have mostly improved disclosure on their own carbon footprint, which is less material to their credit strength than their indirect climate exposures."

—Stephen Nakrosis

Commentary

Worker Shortage Could Bring Back Stagflation

When 10 million jobs remain unfilled and 51% of small-business owners say they can't fill open positions, public policy needs to focus on expanding the labor force and filling job openings, Sen. Ron Johnson writes.

Mr. Johnson, a Republican, is a U.S. senator from Wisconsin.

Venture Capital Hasn't Given Up on China

China's listed internet-technology companies are reeling from a regulatory crackdown, but that hasn't stopped investors from charging into many of the country's technology startups, Jacky Wong writes.

Basis Points

U.S. employers are likely to have added 427,000 payrolls in October, more than the 194,000 job gains registered in September, Oxford Economics said. Economists polled by The Wall Street Journal expect nonfarm payrolls to rise by 450,000. (Dow Jones Newswires)

Positive sentiment among U.S. farmers is slipping, with concern growing about input costs rising ahead of the upcoming growing season, according to a monthly report from Purdue University/CME Group. (DJN)

A private gauge of China's services sector activity maintained robust growth in October, hitting its highest level since July amid the weeklong National Day holiday and relaxation of social-distancing measures. The Caixin China services purchasing managers index rose to 53.8 in October from 53.4 in September, Caixin Media Co. and research company IHS Markit said. (DJN)

Canadian building permits rose in September, as higher construction intentions for multi-family residential units raised the total value of building permits 4.3% from August to a seasonally adjusted 10.14 billion Canadian dollars, or the equivalent of US$8.20 billion, Statistics Canada said. (DJN)

Housing costs in Europe are expected to continue rising, S&P Global Ratings said, noting "residential property markets continue to recover from the pandemic shock more quickly than the rest of the economy." (DJN)

The eurozone factory sector lost further momentum in October, as the regional manufacturing purchasing managers index fell to 58.3 from 58.6 in September due to supply-side problems interrupting production schedules and denting order books. (DJN)

Germany's manufacturing purchasing managers index fell from 58.4 in September to 57.8 in October, as material shortages were a restraining factor for both output and new orders. (DJN)

Singapore's manufacturing activity notched a 16th straight month of expansion as the October reading of its purchasing managers index matched September's 50.8 reading, the Singapore Institute of Purchasing and Materials Management said. A reading above 50 indicates expansion. (DJN)
